Dear authors, at first, congratulations to this important findings. This data, paired with other ancient DNA evidence, can further clarify the demographic patterns of the peopling of Eastern Eurasia and Oceania, as well as their interactions with archaic human groups. Different deeply branching Denisovan components associated with multiple distinct introgression events, are useful additional data points for the possible migration routes and or population substructure scenarios. In your pre-print, you argued for a possible earlier southern route into Oceania, followed by a later wave of the ancestors of South Asians (AASI) and East Asians, with East Asians via a possible northerly route: "This supports an early migration of the ancestors of Oceanians through South Asia followed by the later arrival of the ancestors of present-day South Asians. East Asians do not share this Denisovan component in their genomes, suggesting that their ancestors arrived independently, perhaps by a northerly route". One major problem with this scenario is the observed genetic affinity between the different "basal Asian" populations (e.g. Tianyuan, Ã–nge, Hoabinhian, Xingyi_EN, JÅmon/Shiraho_27k, AASI, and Australasians/Oceanians such as Papuans); also known as "eastern non-Africans" (ENA) or "East Eurasian Core" (EEC). The aDNA data strongly suggest a single dispersal route and subsequent rapid diversification into multiple basal Asian lineages (presumably in the South-Southeast Asia region via a Southern route). E.g. Oceanians/Papuans can successfully be modeled (qpAdm/qpWave) as simply Ã–nge-like + additional Denisovan; or alternatively as Tianyuan-like + additional Denisovan. They do not fit as outgroup to "West/East Eurasians" either, but are nested within the "Eastern" clade. Similarly, present-day East Asians derive most of their ancestry from an Ã–nge-like source, thus could not have arrived there as distinct group by a different route than them. Although it is possible to reproduce a signal affilated with a distinct earlier southern coastal route (proxied by ZlatyKun_45k); this wave however left only minor ancestry among present-day Oceanians/Papuans (and or South Asians), with the majority ancestry of them being derived from the same source as Ã–nge or Tianyuan: e.g. ZlatyKun + Ã–nge-like + extra Denisovan, in a 3â€“13%, 84â€“95%, and 2â€“3% ratio respectively. This means that present-day eastern non-Africans (ENA) descend primarily from a single migration wave eastwards, presumably via a route South of the Himalayas; and which possibly absorbed an earlier less successfull wave, at least regionally (Oceania and South Asia). This may also have happened via a more substructured wave: e.g. both a southern coastal and a southern interior route through South Asia (along the coast of the Indian subcontinent, and via interior routes through India) into Southeast Asia and beyond. Regional Denisovan admixture events (or their partial absence as in the case of JÅmon HGs [see the recent paper by Jiaqi Yang et al. 2025 "An early East Asian lineage with unexpectedly low Denisovan ancestry"]) can be explained that way, without needing several different routes, which would contradict the observed genetic affinities of the different Basal Asian lineages. Note that Tianyuan40k can successfully be modeled as Ã–nge-like + IUP-affilated admixture (BachoKiro_IUP); which fits the presence of IUP material sites in nearby NW China and Mongolia. Such IUP admixture has also been noted to explain the observed affinity to the GoyetQ116-1 specimen in Europe, which similarly can be modeled as Kostenki14/Sunghir_UP + BachoKiro_IUP (see Hajdinjak et al. 2021 "Initial Upper Palaeolithic humans in Europe had recent Neanderthal ancestry"). It is possible that this Siberian IUP group absorbed the EA-specific Denisovan component and via its admixture into Tianyuan, contributed it to other Eastern Asians in lesser amount. â€“ Present-day East Asians in turn can be successfully modeled as Tianyuan-like (c. 25%) + Ã–nge-like (c. 75%); (see McColl et al. 2018 "The prehistoric peopling of Southeast Asia" for example). Alternatively, the primary ancestral source of all eastern non-Africans (ENA) used a northern route through Central Asia/Siberia (e.g. = Siberian IUP), followed by a deep split into Tianyuan-like and "southern ENA" branches. The Tianyuan-like group absorbed the EA-specific Denisovan ancestry, while the "southern ENA" headed into Southern China, where they absorbed the SEA/shared Denisovan component. â€“ One branch of the "southern ENA" likely split prior to this archaic introgression, heading to the Japanese archipelago (being partly ancestral to the JÅmon HGs [Shiraho_27k?], with low or nearly no Denisovan ancestry). For more information on the Shiraho_27k specimen, please contact your co-author Svante PÃ¤Ã¤bo. After the archaic introgression, the "southern ENA" further diversified: one branch became ancestral to the Ã–nge, the Hoabinhians, and the major source of present-day East Asians respectively, as well as the supposed Tibetan Ghost (Xingyi_EN). Such Ã–nge-like ancestry also headed into South Asia, absorbing a possible earlier southern route group and deep Denisovan ancestry = AASI; the same applies for the group heading into Oceania and becoming ancestral to Papuans (Ã–nge-like + deep Denisovan + possible minor earlier wave). A possible Tianyuan->Han->Ã–nge->Papuan cline was also noted by Lazaridis et al. 2018; supplementary information. You can also review Bennett et al. 2024 "Reconstructing the Human Population History of East Asia through Ancient Genomics", a recent summary paper on the peopling of Eastern Asia and beyond; as well as Tianyi Wang et al. 2025 "Prehistoric genomes from Yunnan reveal ancestry related to Tibetans and Austroasiatic speakers". Although the demographic history of Eastern Eurasia is not the main topic of your paper, it is related to the inferred migration routes discussed in your paper, and a relevant additional information; perhaps for future papers, combining aDNA, archaic introgression events/components and archaeologic and environmental data, to present a better picture on the demographic patterns of Paleolithic Eurasia. A summary of my points regarding your postulated "earlier southern route" for Oceanians: â€¢ The available genetic data strongly suggests a single shared migration wave for the primary ancestral source  of all eastern non-Africans (Papuans, AASI, East Asians, Ã–nge/Hoabinhian, and Tianyuan), regardless of via a Northern or Southern route. The presence of multiple deeply branching EEC lineages in Southeast Asia and southern China suggest it to be a major place of diversification from a shared ancestral source. â€¢ Papuans/Oceanians (and AASI) may have limited amounts of admixture from an earlier (southern route) wave, but primarily share ancestry with Ã–nge and Tianyuan. â€¢ Tianyuan can be modeled as either an admixture between Ã–nge-like (61â€“67%) and BachoKiro_IUP-like (33â€“39%) ancestries; or represents a deep split from the rest of eastern non-Africans, staying in the North. â€¢ Ancient and present-day East Asians can be modeled as primarily Ã–nge-like (c. 75%) with Tianyuan-like admixture (c. 25%). â€¢ The IUP-affilated groups, such as BachoKiro_IUP, appear basal to all eastern non-Africans (ENA), but share more affinity with them than West Eurasians (Upper Paleolithic Europeans; Kostenki14 etc.) do. [See also Vallini et al. 2022 and 2024]. â€“ Ust'Ishim forming a "near trifurication" although sharing a short period of evolutionary drift with the ENA/EEC clade. â€¢ The different Denisovan introgression events, if not shared, happened regionally to explain the observed affinities, but differences in Denisovan components. Below some qpAdm results on this (AADR v.62 + Ranis dataset); allsnps=TRUE: Model1 target: Papuan left: Hoabinhian, ZlatyKun, Denisovan right: Mbuti, Ranis13, Ust'Ishim, BachoKiro_IUP, Tianyuan, Ã–nge, Kostenki14, Sunghir_UP Results: Hoabinhian: 93,9%; ZlatyKun: 3,2%; Denisovan: 2,9%; p-value: 0.061 Model2 target: Papuan left: Japan_JÅmon, ZlatyKun, Denisovan right: Mbuti, Ranis13, Ust'Ishim, BachoKiro_IUP, Tianyuan, Kostenki14, Sunghir_UP Results: Japan_JÅmon: 94,1%; ZlatyKun: 2,4%; Denisovan: 3,5%; p-value: 0.094 Model3 target: Tianyuan left: Ã–nge, BachoKiro_IUP right: Mbuti, Ranis13, Ust'Ishim, Oase1_IUP, Papuan, Hoabinhian, Kostenki14, Sunghir_UP Results: Ã–nge: 65,5%%; BachoKiro_IUP: 34,5%%; p-value: 0.170 Model4 target: Japan_JÅmon left: Ã–nge, Amur33k right: Mbuti, Ranis13, Ust'Ishim, BachoKiro_IUP, Tianyuan, Papuan, Hoabinhian, Kostenki14, Sunghir_UP Results: Ã–nge: 79,0%%; Amu33k: 21,0%; p-value: 0.053 Model5 target: Han_Chinese left: Ã–nge, Amur33k right: Mbuti, Ranis13, Ust'Ishim, BachoKiro_IUP, Tianyuan, Papuan, Hoabinhian, Kostenki14, Sunghir_UP Results: Ã–nge: 73,6%%; Amu33k: 26,4%; p-value: 0.090 Etc. (Ã–nge = ONG Mondal; JÅmon = JpOd181/274/282). E.g. it is not likely that Oceanians used a distinct earlier wave into Oceania, separate from other mainland Asian groups. Next to qpAdm/qpWave or qpGraph models, f3/f4 statistics are quite clear on this. Papuans are (beyond their extra Denisovan ancestry and possible minor "earlier group" admixture) nested in eastern non-African diversity (e.g. EEC). I hope this information can help to tangle out some possible scenarios on the dispersal, contact and introgression events for the different deeply branching Denisovan components and present-day Asian populations. I am looking forward for the publication of your paper and more exciting findings! Thank you. Yours sincerely, Yamashita Tatsuya

Pahvantia has been demonstrated to not be a suspension feeder (Caron and Moysiuk, 2021). The "appendage" previously used to calculate mesh size represents the setal blade gills, while the true portion of the appendage obscured alongside it has a Hurdia-like morphology. If possible, Pahvantia should be removed from the analysis.

Hi, I'm on the fence about consensus methods for DA, because these tools are statistical models that do not estimate the same thing (e.g. Aldex measures fold-differences in proportions whereas deseq and edgeR model changes in sequence counts). Also, each model makes different assumption about the data, since they are statistical models. What does the consensus between two tools that target different estimand and have different null hypotheses really mean?

I have only read the Abstract and Introduction, but already I have found multiple issues, as follows. Neither the title nor the Abstract tells us the species under study (mice). The first mention seems to be in Methods. The Introduction does not specify the animal species used in the literature cited (mostly rats, I suppose). Some of the literature citations are erroneous. Here, I focus on two sentences, as follows. "Nicotine is another widely abused drug that both acts on dopamine circuits and has been widely shown to decrease food intake (Iravani, 1972; Passey et al., 1961; Schechter & Cook, 1976)." This sentence requires qualification. Any effect of nicotine on food intake will depend critically on the dose, on acute vs. chronic administration, etc. These three literature citations fail to support the above statement: Iravani 1972 exposed rats to cigarette smoke, not to nicotine per se. It is hardly surprising that the rats lost weight in this 1972 study, as they were reported to show sniffing and sneezing, with post-mortem examination revealing airways filled with "highly purulent fluid". It seems unlikely that this study would obtain ethical approval these days. Passey et al 1961 is from a charity campaign document, which I could not find online and is almost certainly not peer-reviewed. Schechter & Cook, 1976 actually reported the opposite of what is claimed here. This earlier study also used a very high dose of nicotine (0.8 mg/kg expressed as base). Such a dose is near the threshold for producing seizures, and would have given plasma levels of nicotine approximately 10 times higher than in smokers. There are probably dozens of solid papers that could have been cited on nicotine's effects on feeding behaviour in laboratory rats. Not all of these studies suggest that nicotine reduces food intake, especially at doses that might be smoking-relevant. "As with amphetamine, nicotineâ€™s effects on feeding under normal ad libitum feeding conditions has been broadly studied, but its potential effects on the rewarding and motivational qualities of food are unknown." This is a puzzling statement. There are numerous reports of nicotine effects on operant responding for food. Are such studies not relevant?

The methods are very thorough in explaining most of the experimental details. However, there are a few details that could be further expanded on. - A plaque assay was performed on Vero cells, but there are no details on how exactly the assay was conducted. What was the medium used? Was their staining involved? How were the cells counted in the assay? - For the strain ICP0, it is used at an MOI of 10, while the other strains are used at an MOI of 5. Why was an MOI of 10 used rather than the MOI of 5? Was this decided because of previous studies, or were there preliminary tests that were involved? - How were the cells harvested for immunoblotting? - How was the total RNA harvested for extraction? - How were the cells fixed for immunofluorescence? - The authors used a nucGEM of 40nm in size to measure nuclear fluidity. By comparison, what is the size range of HSV-1 virions?

Beautiful work. One aspect that would greatly strengthen the diagnostic claim is the absence of quantitative viral-load information for the 30 nasopharyngeal swab samples in UTM. The preprint reports only RT-qPCR â€˜positiveâ€™ or â€˜negativeâ€™ classifications, without Ct values or titers. Without these data, it remains unclear whether any of the MSD-positive samples represented low viral loads, which is critical for benchmarking clinical sensitivity. Providing Ct values (or approximate genomic copy numbers) for each specimen would substantially increase confidence in the specificity and real-world performance, and this could be gathered within a few days.
It is a nice preprint. However, I find it hard to follow the the text as there is no supporting figures and videos.

Dear colleagues, I read with great interest your preprint describing Tamarixia citricola Hansson and Guerrieri sp. nov. (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae), a putative new parasitoid of Diaphorina citri discovered during a classical biological control program in Cyprus. Congratulations on this interesting contribution to the taxonomy and biological control of psyllid pests. If I may, I would like to respectfully draw your attention to a publication that may be relevant to your study: Burckhardt, D., Yefremova, Z.A., & Yegorenkova, E. (2015). Diaphorina teucrii sp. nov. and its parasitoid Tamarixia dorchinae sp. nov. from the Negev desert, Israel ( Zootaxa 3920 (3): 463â€“473). I apologise for the self-reference, but given the biogeographical proximity and the relevance of the Israeli Tamarixia fauna to the region, it was somewhat surprising not to see it cited. In Israel, we have documented five native species of Tamarixia, including T. dorchinae, which shares several morphological characters with what you describe as T. citricola, particularly in forewing and antennal structure across sexes. A comparative discussion of these taxa might offer further insights into whether the specimens from Cyprus are truly distinct species. A discussion comparing the putative new species with other taxa in the region is warranted anyway. Additionally, I think that host specificity in Tamarixia isgenerally more consistent  with psyllid host genus rather than the associated plant. This ecological pattern may be worth emphasizing in your discussion. We are in the process of barcoding the Tamarixia species of Israel, and a comparison with your material would be most useful. Thank you again for sharing this work,

I really appreciated this ingenious approach, and look forward to exploring some of the concepts raised in my own work (which mainly involves morphological phylogenies â€“ so a rather different scale of dataset).  The rewarding of novelty is a neat trick and it's exciting to see it's so effective, even with a measure as crude as the Robinsonâ€“Foulds.  Given that the RF metric can give misleading representations of tree space (e.g. Smith 2022, https://doi.org/10.1093/sysbio/syab100), I wonder whether you have a sense of whether other tree distance measures might produce even better algorithmic improvements, and how this would trade off against a potentially higher computational cost?

Thanks for your detailed reply! Interesting question about "good-enough" tree distance values â€“ I suppose the answer boils down to "good enough for what", particularly if relationships in one part of a tree are of more interest than those in another.  I'm not sure I'd want to suggest a single universal figure!

FBS is among the most widely used cell culture supplements for in vitro assays and cell manufacturing including GMP-grade clinical products because it is nutrient-rich and supports ex vivo T cell expansion and effector function [1]. We agree that xeno/serum-free cell culture media can improve cell manufacturing quality assurance and safety for clinical-grade cell therapies [2]. Regarding the concern that FBS could be detrimental for the studies in our manuscript, the precursor frequency of FBS-reactive T cells is incredibly low. In the past, we have tested our lots of FBS in various assays (e.g., does it facilitate Treg and Tconv cell expansions and allow for suppression assays?). The actual influence of FBS on the readouts in this manuscript is probably not detectable. Xeno/serum free conditions might be more important for sensitive AIM assays looking for very low frequency precursors. 1	Silva Couto, P. et al. Impact of Serum/Xeno-Free Medium and Cytokine Supplementation on CAR-T Cell Therapy Manufacturing in Stirred Tank Bioreactors. Biotechnol J 20, e70114 (2025). https://doi.org/10.1002/biot.70114 2	Watanabe, N., Mo, F. & McKenna, M. K. Impact of Manufacturing Procedures on CAR T Cell Functionality. Front Immunol 13, 876339 (2022). https://doi.org/10.3389/fimmu.2022.876339

https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.23833 I have published a preprint concluding: 1. All sites contested by Bruttel et al -- those differing between SARS-CoV-2 and one or more of BANAL-20-247, BANAL-20-52, and RaTG13 (Fig 3A) -- are found in closely related genomes. The opposite is expected if these sites were engineered. 2. Equivalent fingerprints can be found for both of the non-bat, SARS2-like, sarbecoviruses (pangolin viruses MP789/Guangdong and P2V/Guangxi). These are both natural genomes. 3. BsaI/BsmBI sites in SARS2 are not anomalously "evenly spaced" when correcting errors made by Bruttel et al and when using a more appropriate metric (coefficient of variance of fragment lengths). One obvious error is dividing 1 by 1429 to obtain 0.07%; 1429 is equal to 71*(6 + choose(6,2)) i.e., the total number of restriction maps generated and not the number "within the ideal range of 5-7 fragments." I also note that "5-8" fragments turns into "5-7 fragments" half way through the manuscript. Things I do not address in my new preprint that are worth noting here: 1. I did not reproduce the "all enzymes" analysis because this is irrelevant to the "IVGA fingerprint" criteria. 2. Like Bruttel et al, I did not investigate whether all sticky ends were unique when calculating significance of the site distribution. 3. I did not reproduce the analysis of mutation rates and types (last two rows of Table S2). First, this is irrelevant because it's very likely that none of these sites are mutated from the most recent common ancestor with recently sampled bat coronaviruses. Second, this is inappropriately circular analysis since the sites were already identified as being different from RaTG13 and BANAL52; of course they will have a excess concentration of differences. Third, these are not "mutations" because SARS-CoV-2 did not evolve from RaTG13 or BANAL52 by "mutation". The null hypothesis is nonsensical. I also did not address point "f" in the "IVGA fingerprint" -- "Two unique recognition sites may flank regions meant to be further manipulated." -- because it is based on false information. Bruttel et al wrote, falsely, that a 2017 paper reported a method "enabling efficient manipulations of the flanking region without having to reassemble the entire viral backbone for each variant." This is false because: 1. The substituted fragment in the 2017 paper was not flanked by BsaI sites in the resulting construct (pBAC-CMV-rWIV1); BsaI sites were not retained in the assembly. 2. There is a BsaI site in the BAC backbone (pBeloBAC11) that is retained. 3. There are 5 BsaI sites in WIV1 that were retained. There was no need to remove them because they occur in fragments that were not digested with BsaI. Of course, one-pot Golden Gate assembly protocols require removing backbone sites to combine restriction digestion and ligation into a single step; but this is not one of them since it is a modification of a previous system, Zeng et al 2016, that used BglI, SacII, and AscI.

A fundamental principle of enzyme kinetics is that the microscopic rate constants for substrate association (kf) and dissociation (kr) cannot be elucidated from steady-state data alone. The reason is that once the enzyme-substrate (ES) complex reaches a steady state, the individual forward and reverse steps of its formation become masked in the overall bulk reaction velocity. Consequently, determining kf and kr necessitates pre-steady-state kinetic measurements. This is intuitively clear when considering two hypothetical enzymes with identical kcat and kcat/Km values but different underlying kf and kr. Such enzymes would produce indistinguishable Michaelis-Menten plots (V vs. [S]), making it impossible to discriminate between their microscopic constants based on steady-state data. The authors' highly mathematical approach appears to overlook this foundational constraint. Beyond this conceptual issue, several methodological choices raise concerns regarding the biological relevance and interpretation of the simulations. 1. Violation of Quasi-Steady-State Approximation (QSSA) Conditions (Page 6) The authors state that initial concentrations s0 and e0 were sampled from intervals Is=[Km/5,1.5Km] and Ie=[Km/50,0.5Km], claiming these adhere to QSSA conditions. However, a critical requirement for the standard QSSA is that the substrate concentration greatly exceeds the enzyme concentration (s0>>e0), typically by two orders of magnitude. This ensures that substrate depletion due to ES complex formation is negligible, allowing the free substrate concentration to be approximated by s0. The chosen intervals, where e0 can be as high as 2.5 times s0 (e.g., s0=0.2Km and e0=0.5Km), severely violate this condition. Therefore, the subsequent simulations and analyses do not accurately model a conventional steady-state experiment, where the QSSA is valid. 2. Unrealistic Kinetic Parameters and Confounded Results (Page 8) In the sensitivity analysis, the authors compare two scenarios: â€¢	(i)   kf=0.500 nMâˆ’1sâˆ’1, kr=0.005 sâˆ’1 â€¢	(ii)  kf=0.005 nMâˆ’1sâˆ’1, kr=0.500 sâˆ’1 The ratio kr/kf defines the dissociation constant (Kd). For scenario (i), Kd=10 pM, representing an exceptionally tight, nearly irreversible binding event that is thermodynamically implausible for a productive enzyme-catalyzed reaction. In contrast, scenario (ii) has a more reasonable Kd of 10 ÂµM. More critically, these scenarios are again simulated with e0 comparable to s0, invalidating the QSSA. Furthermore, the two parameter sets result in different Km values (approximately 10 nM and 300 nM, respectively). The different substrate decay curves shown in Figure 1 are therefore a direct result of different enzyme saturation levels (s0/Km ratios), not a unique sensitivity to kr. If the simulations were repeated with identical s0/Km ratios and appropriately scaled timeframes, the substrate decay profiles would be indistinguishable. This confounding factor also explains the reported low sensitivity to kr: when kr<<kcat, the value of Km becomes insensitive to changes in kr. Conclusion In summary, this work does not demonstrate that microscopic rate constants kf and kr can be derived from steady-state parameters Km and kcat. The simulations were conducted under conditions that violate the assumptions of Michaelis-Menten model, and the presented results appear to be confounded by differences in enzyme saturation. The parameter sets were selected in a manner that produced the desired outcome rather than exploring a biologically realistic parameter space. Ultimately, these findings indirectly reinforce the established consensus: obtaining microscopic rate constants requires pre-steady-state kinetic analysis Alessandro Pesaresi CNR, Institue of Crystallography, Trieste alessandro.pesaresi@cnr.it

Apologies readers, but Figure 4 caption is incorrect. It should read:"Figure 4: (A) The MR-PMM shows a significant positive correlation between cranial shape and cranial centroid size within a phylogenetic context (confidence interval well above zero), while there was no evidence for such a correlation outside of the context. There is also a significant residual correlation indicating within-species allometry. (B) Variance decomposition of both cranial size and the shape regression score indicates high phylogenetic structuring of both variables."

The lysosome aspect of this work is intriguing and can certainly shift the understanding of HPV entry pathways. However, it is completely inaccurate to state that "direct visualization of the virus in membrane-bound vesicles has not been achieved" (end of introduction). TEM analysis clearly demonstrated virions within vesicles attached to the mitotic chromosomes in previous work (Day et al. J Virol. 93, e00454-19 (2019).
This work has been updated, peer reviewed and published. See: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38795347/

Hi Pete Thank you ! Yes - the motivation for the analysis in the paper was our observation that there is loss in demuxing efficiency when we do routine pools with all hashtags (in other experiments with 14-16 hashtags) in all wells. So this analysis did confirm our initial concern;  but it was nice to see the regression fit so well with the number of hashtags used. I think that helps pick a sweetspot in experiment design, depending on how valuable the samples are. appreciate your comments, nevil

For the article, Divalent siRNA for prion disease, the methods used seem appropriate; however, authors should provide more details on why specific techniques were used. Monovalent siRNA was mentioned multiple times, which was confusing because the project is focused on divalent siRNAs. There were many times where it said to â€œsee aboveâ€ but it was unclear where to look. In addition, Figure 1 is unclear and needs additional labeling. The text says Chol-TEG s1 is monovalent, but that is not indicated in the figure. Figure 2 demonstrates that siRNA extends the lifespan of mice exposed to prion particles, but it is not shown in the humanized mice and 2439-s4. Why is it not the same? The section expanded screen for potent human siRNA sequences, discusses cell death but did not explain the technique used and why the authors chose that technique. For example, it was described as â€œany wells with cell death or rounded cells were noted.â€ Clarification on how authors determined if the cells underwent cell death or if they were rounded is needed. In addition, the generated mouse line description is unclear. Are the C57BL/6 mice replaced with human locus? The generation of the mice used for the experiments is not described sufficiently. Specifically, the transgenic mice were back crossed until generation 5; however, the following section discussed using generation 3 and 6 for transgene mapping. Furthermore, how much murine DNA was removed and how much human DNA was inserted? Is it the same chromosomal location? In addition, there needs to be a better explanation on how the targeted siRNA dose levels were chosen, simply saying â€œdetermined by UV absorbanceâ€ is not enough. The administration of divalent siRNA to mice was unclear. Why were two different types of anesthesia used? The statement â€œthis procedure was performed first on the right and then on the leftâ€ needs to be explained.  A figure detailing the procedure would help. How was the location of injection (between the right ear and midline) was chosen? Finally, why use ChatGPT to generate a Python script? How was the script deemed accurate? The use and accuracy of using ChatGPT needs to be clarified.

ROI selection based on minimal cosine distance yields centrally homogeneous nodes, biasing analyses toward within-network conformity and ignoring functional heterogeneity; the V1 ROIâ€™s failure to replicate in an independent dataset suggests findings may be stimulus-specific rather than generalizable assumed linear relationship between FC change and geodesic distance w/o formally testing whether model provided best fit to data, potentially obscuring complex non-linear relationships did not account for spatial autocorrelation across nearby brain regions, potentially violating independence assumptions and inflating false-positive risk analyses did not involve separate tests across all 360 brain regions, so stringent multiple-comparison correction was not needed controlled for mean FC by residualizing MRD and geodesic distance, potentially removing meaningful connectivity variance if intrinsic connection strength influences reorganization core analysis used residualized MRD and geodesic distance; repeating it on raw MRD and distance values could clarify whether residualization affects the results

Isn't there an issue when adding FBS to a human ex-vivo model? Using fetal bovine serum in human pancreatic tissue slice cultures introduces xenogeneic components that compromise physiological relevance. Human cells are exposed to bovine proteins, immunoglobulins, cytokines, and growth factors they would never encounter in vivo. This is especially concerning for immune cell studies, where bovine mediators may inappropriately activate or suppress human macrophages and T cells, producing non-physiological responses. Species differences in growth factor-receptor interactions can alter signaling pathways and gene expression, creating artifacts that don't reflect authentic human biology. For mechanistic studies and therapeutic evaluations, maintaining species-appropriate culture conditions is critical. We recommend using human serum (autologous or pooled) or chemically defined serum-free media with human recombinant proteins. This ensures observations reflect genuine human tissue responses rather than culture artifacts, improving both scientific rigor and translational relevance.

I enjoyed reading this, thank you. Have you thought about a 'fully replicated Design-V', i.e. 6 wells where each well contains all 12 samples? Intuitively, having total experimental replication across wells strikes me as optimal, and is a design we use frequently, but your observation that pools with increasing numbers of HTOs have poorer demultiplexing suggests a downside I'd not considered. Thanks, Pete

Why does abstract say "We investigated..." but there is only one author? The labeling is unclear. The Methods section says â€œlabeled solution was mixed with E. coli and added to NGM plate, and also label solution was added to eggs.â€ Why both times? In the introduction the linking of the visualizing glycosylation in vivo tool and O-GIcNA is unclear. It may be a good tool but how does it relate to the protein? Why did the authors use this visualization process? In the O-GlcNAc Sites Labeling Protocol section the authors say that they cared to pelletize the worms after the incubation procedure, but do not explain why they take special care to do that. In the Microscopy Settings section, last paragraph, the article say that they did some preliminary testing to optimize all the parameter choices but do not explain what tests were done.  In the image processing section, the paper says they tested different LUTs to make sure the background changed on the image, but it does not say what tests were used for that.  In the tracking analysis section, it says there is a â€œconverting spots to Regions of Interestâ€ node was created. Was that created by the system or manually by the scientists?  Overall, this paper gives good descriptions (apart from those listed above) if anyone wanted to replicate the experiment, which is very appreciated.

This is a very interesting study highlighting the role of seminal plasma molecules in regulating sperm capacitation-related events. These findings are consistent with those of Zalazar et al. (2020, doi:10.3389/fcell.2020.575126), showing that another seminal plasma protein, SPINK3 â€”originating from the seminal vesicleâ€” also modulates CatSper activity and hyperactivation. The presence of multiple molecules with apparently redundant functions strengthens the concept of fine-tuning exerted by seminal plasma proteins on sperm capacitation. Additionally, have you explored what happens when excess of EPPIN is added regarding SEMG1â€™s effects on sperm?

Some of the conclusions from this study are not aligned with the state-of-the-art concerning yeast phylogenomics. Unfortunately, it is difficult to ascertain how the authors came to their conclusions because figure legends are missing and the methods are incomplete and do not explain, for example, the approaches used to establish orthology. In particular,  the species phylogenies presented are inconsistent with previous findings. Widely accepted, uncontroversial yeast phylogenomic trees can be consulted in the following corner-stone study from the Hittinger and Rokas labs: https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.adj4503
Today, this preprint was published at Communications Biology and is available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s42003-025-09010-x. An official update of this preprint with linked DOI is forthcoming.

Interesting work .. two comments/suggestions for your consideration: For plankton, one of the major routes to establish whether something is critical is to have it described in a simulation and conduct a sensitivity analysis. The problem is that the sorts of details in this work never get into plankton models. This disparity between especially omics and models has been raised most recently by Flynn et al. (2025) https://doi.org/10.1038/s41559-025-02788-3. It would be really helpful for you to flag how this work could usefully inform next generation plankton models. My second point concerns 'mixotroph'. From the tone of the discussion on this point, I assume you refer to photo-phagotrophy, as undertaken by mixoplankton. The problem with 'mixotroph' is that diatoms are strongly mixotrophic, via photo-osmotrophy (a trait well studied back in the 1960's etc. and exploited in algal biotech). I suggest that you consider using 'mixoplankton' to identify those organisms which are photo-phagotrophic. Checking organisms against the contents of the Mixoplankton Data Base of Mitra et al. (2023) https://doi.org/10.1111/jeu.12972, may help as this catalogues trophic modes and many other features of these organisms.

This study by Bento et. al (2024) revealed that both Anopheles mosquitoes and plasmodium parasites are influenced by rhythms that have evolved to synchronize in order to optimize infection and transmission timing within the hole. Researchers asked whether the biological clocks helped the organism anticipate blood meals and modulate, parasite behavior, which would ultimately affect malaria transmission. There are three primary findings in this paper. The first finding was that roughly half of the mosquito salivary gland transcriptome exhibit 24 hour rhythmic expression. The expression peaks occurred twice daily once early in the day and once early in the night, which alliance with the gnome mosquito feeding patterns. These changes persist in both light/dark (LD) and constant darkness (DD) conditions. This was an indication that the genes in the salivary glands were driven by an internal circadian clock rather than by light cues or environmental factors. The second finding is that the Plasmodium sporozoite in the salivary gland also show cyclic transcription, that included cells involved in motility and host cell invasion. The authors ruled out the possibility that the observed rhythmic expression could be due to changes in sporozoite numbers due to replication or migration. After using immunofluorescence to visualize sporozoites at specific time points and testing for DNA replication, they found no evidence that replication explained the cyclic patterns. These results strengthened to idea that both mosquito and parasite are synchronized by daily cycles. Lastly, the found that mosquitoes are more likely feed at night and ingest more blood. Mice infected with sporozoites at night show higher liver parasites loads than mice infected during the day, indicating that sporozoites more infective at night. Together, these results suggest that the mammalian host, Plasmodium parasite and the Anopheles mosquito have evolved coordinated daily rhythms that maximize transmission success. The paperâ€™s central contribution is the discovery that both the Anopheles mosquito vector and the Plasmodium parasite operate under circadian control and that their biological rhythms are synchronized to optimize malaria transmission. A critique that I would give to the main contribution is that experiments use Anopheles mosquitoes and Plasmodium berghei (a rodent malaria model). While appropriate for a controlled lab setting, it does not fully represent human malaria species or the natural mosquito environment. Conducting similar experiment in the future on human malaria parasites and field collected mosquitoes would strength relevance to the human population. If I were to write the significance of the paper on a 1-5 scale, I would give it a 4. It provides an important discovery with clear implication for control strategies. Overall, the methodology is mostly convincing. The researchers sampling every 4 hours, replication cross LD and DD conditions and combined transcriptomic and proteomic approaches provide a strong support for the presence of rhythmic gene expression. However, I have some questions about the results. The paper shows differences in expression levels between LD and DD conditions. What explains the discrepancies. This study would benefit from more discussion or experiments that addressed the source of LD and DD differences. Also, not all genes within the sporozoite showed clean cyclic patterns. For example, p52, CS, and AMA-1, displayed irregular or weak oscillations. It would be helpful if the authors addressed whether their irregulars reflect true biological variability or something external among the sporozoites. Also, a direct manipulation of clock components would strength the link between salivary gland genes and sporozoites. The most important limitation is generalizability. This studyâ€™s experiments focused on rodent-parasite/mosquito system under controlled conditions. This makes it unclear whether the observed data of rhythmic gene expression operates identically in natural setting with human malaria species and diverse mosquito environments. I would rate the writing 3/5 for clarity. The methodâ€™s section was dense and difficult to follow in some parts. There were technical terms and procedural details that were not fully explained for a non-specialist reader. For example. algorithms were named (e.g., ARSER, JTK_CYCLE), but a brief, plain-language description of what each contributes would help readers unfamiliar with circadian statistics. Also, some of the figures lacked proper labeling so it as hard to interpret what the data without having to refer back to the paper. Â However, the abstract, introduction, results and discussion were readable and logically organized. Overall, the paper reframes malaria as a time-dependent system in which the vector, parasite and host rhythms are important for infection and transmission. Practical implication includes creating strategies that uses this knowledge such as insecticide spraying, bed-net use or prophylactic drug delivery to disrupt transmission timing. Moreover, this study can extend to other vector-borne disease such as Zika and dengue. Ultimately, this research contributes to the growing appreciation that temporal organization is central to biological function.

Thanks for the very interesting preprint. I had a few questions: Since the analysis reuses public datasets, could upstream biases affect PCN estimates? Did you try any sensitivity checks? Many assemblies donâ€™t include clear isolation/source info. If metadata are available, would stratifying by source (clinical vs environmental, host/body site) change the main patterns? Some taxa (e.g., E. coli/Enterobacterales) seem over-represented. Do the sizeâ€“PCN trend and the ~2.5% DNA-load rule still hold after down-sampling or re-weighting? Do you plan a small wet-lab validation or tests in more distant taxa to see how broadly these rules generalize? Thanks againâ€”really exciting direction!

Thank you for sharing some really thorough work in investigating the mechanism of IFNÎ± induction in relation to the attenuation of the live measles vaccine! I really appreciated how comprehensive the explanations were for each methodology. The decision-making made a lot of sense through the narrative presented, especially with the supplemental figures. It was very interesting to see how your results led to the conclusion that IFNÎ± induction contributes to LAMV attenuation. At the end of the discussion, you mention the possibility of alternative vaccination options for those who are immunocompromised. What do you think those alternatives would look like? Would it be further attenuating the current LAMV, or would it use a different vaccine vector altogether? In the introduction, you noted the current cultural rise in vaccine hesitancy. Given its impact on recent vaccine uptake trends, Iâ€™m curious what you would consider the best method to effectively communicate this workâ€™s findings to those who are vaccine hesitant. Is there anything you think is particularly compelling that could be communicated to the general public, particularly the vaccine hesitant or science skeptical crowd? Finally, Iâ€™d like to leave a small suggestion: would you consider adjusting some of the figures to a more colorblind-friendly palette of colors (particularly for Figure 1E)? This could help make some of the figuresâ€™ details easier to distinguish and make your research more accessible to a wider audience. Thank you again for such an interesting and wonderful read!

I enjoyed reading this preprint very much. I found the logical flow of the experiments quite smooth and elegant, starting with mosquitoes and the parasites and finally the hosts, as well as using the methods of sequencing and behavioural studies. I also appreciated the comprehensive approach that connects the efficiency of malaria transmission to the genetic and behavioural aspects between the host, vector and parasite. I particularly liked how you incorporated both mRNA sequencing and proteomic analyses to strengthen your conclusions, though it might help to clarify some figures (e.g., clearer axis labeling in hierarchical clustering and heat maps, discussing patterns in heat maps) and discuss potential experimental limitations, such as the frequency of proteomic sampling and how experimental settings, such as the single-bloodmeal design differs from natural conditions. Overall, this is an innovative piece of work which sets a foundation for future circadian and malaria studies.

As a student interested in both circadian activity and microbiology, I found this study especially exciting. Your work provides remarkable insight into how circadian rhythms influence malaria transmission, connecting parasite, vector, and host biology in a way that could reshape how we think about disease timing and control strategies. One question I have is regarding the difference in the number of peaks and the timing of peak expression activity between the mosquitoes and the sporozoites shown in fig. 1F and fig. 3C. Iâ€™m interested in what you make of the discrepancy. Why might it be advantageous for sporozoites to have a peak expression in the early morning while most of the Anopheles activity occurs. The fact that the peak expressions are synched between the sporozoites suggests that they are synched by external stimulus. However, for an immature parasite that likely lacks photoreceptors and was raised under constant temperature, Iâ€™m really curious what type of stimulus could affix or synchronize its circadian rhythm. I really enjoyed reading this thought-provoking piece of work.

In this paper, the authors generated a large-scale single-cell transcriptomic atlas of Trypanosoma cruzi, covering over 31,000 cells across all major life cycle stages.They identified transcriptionally distinct subpopulations of two different trypomastigotes and mapped metacyclogenesis through pseudotime trajectory analysis. The study also highlights RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) as potential key regulators of developmental gene expression changes in T. cruzi. The main contribution is the creation of the first comprehensive scRNA-seq atlas of T. cruzi, which provides a high-quality resource for understanding life cycle transitions. This dataset provides a foundational reference that future studies can use to build new RNA-seq experiments and explore regulatory mechanisms in parasite development. The primary limitation is that the study is descriptive rather than mechanistic. The authors identify candidate regulators and stage-specific genes but do not experimentally test their functional roles, leaving relationships unproven. Overall, this is a technically strong and biologically revealing preprint that significantly advances the research field of the life cycle of the T. cruzi. Despite some limitations in experimental validation, the datasetâ€™s scale, quality, and analytical depth make it a valuable work.

Itâ€™s a really well-designed study with clear logic and strong experimental support. First, the authors nicely identified the key mechanism of attenuation â€” an early and strong IFN-Î± response that limits measles virus replication. I also like how they combined in vivo and in vitro experiments, which makes the findings much more convincing. And finally, the study not only explains why the measles vaccine is safe and long-lasting, but also gives useful insights for designing new live or IFN-sensitive vaccine platforms. That said, there are still a few details that could be improved. For example, in Figure 1aâ€“b, itâ€™s not very clear why the authors only used TECs and PBMCs as models instead of including other cell types. Itâ€™s also not explained why they only collected the supernatant from TECs but measured both the supernatant and cell fractions in PBMCs. In Figure 4, the macaque experiment only shows viral RNA and cytokine changes in BAL and PBMCs, but lacks tissue-level analysis like immune cell infiltration or histology. Lastly, the study doesnâ€™t really discuss the adaptive immune response, which is important since long-term immune memory is a major feature of the measles vaccine. Overall, I think itâ€™s an excellent paper with strong data and meaningful findings, but there are still some details that could be clarified or expanded to make it even stronger.

This preprint presents a rigorous and thought-provoking study that overturns the common assumption that greater forest heterogeneity always promotes biodiversity. Using large-scale manipulative experiments across eleven German beech forest sites and sophisticated coverage-standardized analyses with Hill numbers, the authors demonstrate that structural diversification can actually reduce local and landscape-scale spider diversity through strong habitat filtering, even though species turnover slightly increases. The integration of taxonomic, functional, and phylogenetic dimensions provides a comprehensive picture of how community assembly responds to silvicultural heterogenization. Overall, this work offers important insights into the scale-dependent and taxon-specific consequences of forest management and reminds ecologists that complexity does not universally translate into higher diversity.

Thank you for your excellent work in the important ecological field of temperate forest heterogeneity and its impact on spider diversity.  This is a surprising and interesting finding that structural heterogeneity increases Î² diversity but decreasesÂ Î³Â and Î±Â diversity. Your large-scale and rigorous experimental designÂ provides solid support for your results, and I think it can potentially guide the ecological management of modern forestry. However, to fully maximize the value of your research, I think you can have deeper interpretation of your results. For example, you can provide anÂ analysis of key heterogeneity indicators such as deadwood type and the presence/absence of gaps in ESBC district. I also suggest that you can emphasise the significance and impact of your research more in the discussion part. The paper's overall logical flow is clear, and the writing is fluent. Although some technical terms make it difficult for readers without an ecological background to read, I consider this a good article. Thanks for your work!

I think this research provides valuable insights on the transmission of malaria can be affected by the circadian rhythms in Anopheles mosquitos and Plasmodium parasites. The abstract in this paper is very clear as it provides both background information and key findings. One thing I suggest is considering adding a short summary of methods used so the audience can get a basic idea about how you study the mechanisms of circadian rhythms. For the method section, I have some questions: 1)Why do you choose to dissect the salivary glands of mosquitos every 4 hours instead of with other time intervals? Are there previous studies or specific mechanisms in mosquito biology that support 4-hour interval is most optimal for this study? 2) I think other factors such as moisture and temperature may also play a role in altering circadian rhythms in mosquitos. Have you considered incoporate those factors in future studies? If so, how will you control them in a laboratory setting? 3) For this study, is it necessary to include a group of uninfected mosquitos as control? I think it'd be better to have them so you can have a baseline to compare with because circadian rhythms may be affected by the parasites. Lastly, I wonder how the parasites know the mosquito's circadian rhythm and adjust their own gene expression accordingly? Are there specific communication mechanisms or signaling pathway that may contribute to this coordination between mosquitos and parasites?

This manuscript is strong in logic. The authors choose 2 models and use them to validate a clear post-entry restriction for LAMV. They separate entry/transcription from productive replication with layered readouts and align these with signaling kinetics (p-STAT1/2, ISGs), so the causal link to rapid IFN-Î± activation feels credible rather than assumed. Figures and statistics are proportional to the claims, and the writing stays close to the data, avoiding overreach.    I have one question for IFN-Î², the data emphasize IFN-Î± (transcripts/protein and signaling), and IFN-Î² appears lower, but its functional contribution is not directly excluded.Do you plan to do more experiment to further exclude IFN-Î²?

Peer Review Materials and Methods: Phosphoproteomics uncovers rapid and specific transition from plant two-component system signaling to Ser/Thr2phosphorylation by the intracellular redox sensor AHK531 Not necessarily relegated to materials and methods sections of the article but found throughout the abstract and introduction is a lack of background in the subject along with relevance to the continuance of research in this field and importance to biology. Typical diploid organism experimental design studying a specific genotype for expression involves using a homozygous wild-type (+/+), heterozygous mutant with one copy of the allele (+/-), and a homozygous mutant with the gene knocked out (-/-). This study only utilized Arabidopsis ahk5-1 (Col-0) as their homozygous mutant and compared the treatment with the wild-type homozygous Arabidopsis. Why was the heterozygote not included in the study? Is there any phenotypic difference between the WT and the knockout strain? Growth rates, appearance, stress tolerance, etc.? If the AHK5 gene is critical in signaling during stress, there should be a phenotype of deficient stress tolerance. The experimental design also did not involve replicants or parallel experiments during the metabolic labeling procedures Another problematic issue is the type of water used. During the treatment stage, the control â€œmockâ€ treatment added an equivalent amount of water to the seedlings but does not specify the type of water (i.e. DI water vs. tap). Later, after incubation of the treatment methods, the seedlings are rinsed specifically with tap water. Components of tap water vs. DI water can have differences in mineral content and affect the protein extraction results. The protein extraction procedure was modified where instead of grinding in a mortar and pestle as per procedures established2,3, the liquid nitrogen frozen plant matter was coarsely crushed. The reasoning for this was not established. During the proteome quantification procedure, hits to contaminants were excluded. Why was this? Contaminants added during the procedures could remain undetected because of this. References (1)	Drechsler, T.; Li, Z.; Schulze, W. X.; Harter, K. Phosphoproteomics Uncovers Rapid and Specific Transition from Plant Two-Component System Signaling to Ser/Thr Phosphorylation by the Intracellular Redox Sensor AHK5. October 14, 2025. https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.10.13.682113. (2)	Dautel, R. MOLECULAR CHARACTERIZATION OF THE ARABIDOPSIS THALIANA HISTIDINE KINASE 1; 2016. (3)	Wu, X. N.; Schulze, W. X. Phosphopeptide Profiling of Receptor Kinase Mutants. Methods in Molecular Biology 2015, 1306, 71â€“79. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4939-2648-0_5.

This preprint addresses a longstanding question in vaccinology by proposing and experimentally supporting a mechanistic explanation for why the live-attenuated measles vaccine (LAMV) is safe yet immunogenic.This is a strong, well-executed study that convincingly shows LAMV is restricted in primary immune cells by an early IFN-Î±â€“driven innate response. The authors present a coherent body of evidence showing that LAMV, unlike wild-type measles virus (MeV), triggers an early, robust type I interferon response (dominated by IFN-Î±) in primary human PBMCs; this response correlates with a post-entry block in infectious particle formation. The experimental program is broad and well-integrated: bulk RNA-Seq, targeted protein analyses (TBK1/IRF3/IRF7/STAT1), cytokine profiling, functional IFN pathway blockade, reverse genetics and validation in rhesus macaques.Using a combination of primary human PBMCs, differentiated rhesus tracheal epithelial cells, reverse genetics, and an in vivo macaque model, the authors show that LAMV uniquely triggers an early and robust type I interferon response dominated by IFN-Î± in immune cells. The data are coherent across molecular, functional, and animal-model levels and together provide a compelling model that innate immune activation rather than an inherent replication defect is the dominant driver of LAMV attenuation. The study has several notable strengths. It is a multi-layered experimental design.Use of primary human PBMCs and an in vivo macaque model is especially important, since the attenuation phenotype is largely invisible in immortalized cell lines that have compromised interferon responses. The integration of genetic (mutation) data with host-response profiling produces a clear and translationally relevant mechanistic narrative that is likely of interest to both virologists and vaccine developers. The paper shows that innate IFN responses tied to specific mutations drive attenuation has broad implications for rational live-vaccine design and safety considerations (including immunocompromised hosts). It is not a paradigm-shifting discovery for immunology generally, but it is a significant, field-advancing contribution to vaccine virology. There is however one concern that I have is that, although macaque experiments add in vivo relevance, intratracheal infection may not fully model the subcutaneous/intramuscular context of human vaccination; additional delivery-route experiments would bolster translational claims. Overall speaking about the format , the preprint is well organized and easy to follow and the Methods and Supplementary files provide sufficient technical detail to reproduce the core experiments. Figures are logically ordered to match the results narrative, and most figure legends succinctly summarize what is shown.This paper suggests a shift in thinking about live-attenuated vaccine design attenuation can be achieved deliberately by engineering viruses to induce targeted innate responses (especially type I IFNs) while retaining sufficient antigen expression to drive durable adaptive immunity. That concept could guide rational design of next-generation live vaccines or adjuvant strategies.Overall, this is an important and timely study that links viral genetics and host innate immunity to vaccine attenuation.

This looks like an interesting and valuable study. There are a couple of additional recent AOA virus publications that might be relevent for your analyses ( 10.1038/s41396-022-01341-5; 10.1093/ismejo/wrae205). Also just wanted to mention it is ammonia-oxidizing archaea.

This paper provides a clear and quantitative analysis of plasmid copy number (PCN) across thousands of bacterial genomes. The authors confirm a universal scaling law between plasmid size and PCN, showing that plasmid DNA load is conserved relative to chromosome size. I found the idea of â€œreplicon dominanceâ€ in multi-replicon plasmids particularly interesting, as it explains how merged plasmids resolve replication conflicts. The study is significant because it formalizes long-standing assumptions about plasmid replication using a large comparative dataset. I wonder if the authors have performed any wet-lab experiments to test the â€œreplicon dominanceâ€ rule in controlled conditions. I am looking forward to seeing how this line of research progresses!

This is a well-written paper that presents a clear and logical design of experiments using the ESBC method, supported by thorough data analysis and thoughtful interpretation. The introduction effectively highlights the current challenges in modern silviculture and their potential impacts on biodiversity, providing a strong foundation for the study. I particularly appreciate how well the discussion is structured. It not only ties the findings back to the significance of the study but also offers deep insights into the ecological implications of Î±, Î², and Î³ diversity. This reflective linkage between empirical results and theoretical context makes the discussion compelling and meaningful. However, one aspect that could be improved is the relatively monotonous presentation of diversity data. The results for Î±, Î², and Î³ diversity could be made more engaging by incorporating alternative visualization approaches, for example, heatmaps, cluster plots, or even ordination diagrams like NMDS (Non-metric Multidimensional Scaling), if applicable. These would enhance the interpretability of spatial or compositional patterns. Additionally, relying solely on pitfall traps may introduce sampling bias toward specific taxa or behaviors. Incorporating complementary methods, such as leaf-litter extraction or flight intercept traps, could yield a more comprehensive representation of the community composition and strengthen the ecological conclusions. Overall, this is a strong and well-structured study with clear scientific value, and with a few adjustments to data visualization and sampling design, it could be even more impactful.

We at the Evolutionary Health Group ( https://evoheal.github.io/) really enjoyed this paper. Here are our highlights: The authors combine small DNA motif signatures with larger pan-genome features to predict antibiotic resistance, outperforming models that use only target motifs or only genome-wide features. This dual model demonstrates improved generalization across multiple bacterial species. The approach also evaluates the relative predictive value of individual motifs.

I really enjoyed reading your paper â€” among those Iâ€™ve reviewed, it stood out for its excellent organization. The clear structure of abstract, introduction, methods, results, discussion, and conclusion made it easy to follow the logical flow of the study. I especially appreciated the formatting and figure legends, particularly Figure 3, which made the results very intuitive to interpret. The results section also aligns well with the visual data, which helped reinforce your conclusions. If I may offer a small suggestion, it would be to provide brief explanations of some technical terms in earlier sections. As someone outside the field of ecology, I found concepts such as Hill numbers (q = 0, 1, 2) and their relationship to Î±-, Î²-, and Î³-diversity or TD/FD/PD facets a bit difficult to grasp on first reading, even though the discussion later clarified them well. It might also help to elaborate slightly on the ecological roles of deadwood and canopy density in shaping forest structural complexity and why these features are particularly relevant to spiders. Overall, the paper is clear, well-written, and thoughtfully presented. The points Iâ€™ve raised are minor and come mainly from the perspective of a reader less familiar with ecological terminology. Thank you for sharing such a well-organized and insightful piece of work.

We identified minor annotation errors in the tissue-of-origin labels for several cell lines in Figure 2f. These color assignments have been corrected. The underlying data, analysis pipeline, and interpretations are unaffected. Please see https://zenodo.org/records/17344720 for the updated version.

This is an excellent study with a clearly organized article. Using rigorous in vitro and in vivo models, the authors demonstrate that, unlike wild-type measles, LAMV infection of primary human immune cells induces a potent innate response driven by IFNÎ±, effectively inhibiting viral replication and spread. Furthermore, by co-infection of PBMCs and rhesus macaque cells, they clearly demonstrate that LAMV can enter cells and initiate transcription but is unable to produce progeny virus, consistent with its robust innate sensing capabilities. One question is how these acute innate signals influence vaccine immunogenicity: the authors note that LAMV also triggers rapid release of proinflammatory cytokines in PBMC cultures and rhesus macaques, which may contribute to the initiation of adaptive immunity. It would be helpful if the authors could elaborate on whether and how the early IFNÎ± and cytokine responses they observed contribute to the long-term protective immunity elicited by LAMV (e.g., by enhancing antigen presentation or memory formation). Overall, this well-executed study provides a compelling mechanistic framework explaining why LAMV is both safe and highly immunogenic, and the proposed elucidation will further strengthen the link between innate responses and vaccine efficacy.
It has been published: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41561-022-01081-3
This article has now been published: https://animalmicrobiome.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s42523-021-00136-x

This paper provides a very creative and integrative view of fungal evolution, especially in functions of fungal effectors. I think the authors connect molecular biology, ecology, and evolutionary reasoning into one story is very great, showing that fungal effectors may have originated from ancient antimicrobial proteins. And the tool AMAPEC is well designed, and it is the key method in this research. Also, the narrative is clear, well supported by data. One small suggestion would be to strengthen the evolutionary argument with more structural or functional validation. Since the conclusions rely heavily on computational predictions, additional experimental evidence, especially under natural microbiome conditions, in this way, it could make the findings even more convincing.
